clinical_study.brief_title: Anterior Insula Regulation and Pain Empathy
clinical_study.official_title: Voluntary Anterior Insula Regulation Impacts Pain Empathy and Functional Connectivity: a Real-time fMRI Study

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China

clinical_study.source: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China

brief_summary.textblock: The aim is to test whether rtfMRI-based neurofeedback training on anterior insula impacts pain empathy.

detailed_description.textblock: In the present study, investigators plan to use the real-time fMRI neurofeedback to train healthy subjects to learn volitional control over their own anterior insula (AI) activity. Then the effect of AI regulation will assessed by examining subjects' empathic responses and functional connectivity changes. Subjects were separated into two groups randomly. While the experimental group received specific neurofeedback from their own AI, the control group received sham NF from an unspecific region.

primary_outcome.measure: neural activity of anterior insula during neorofeedback training

clinical_study.condition: Empathic Responses After Anterior Insula Regulation

arm_group.description: Neurofeedback training group receives neurofeedback from their own anterior insula.
Sham control group receives sham neurofeedback from a large control brain region.

intervention.intervention_name: real-time fMRI neurofeedback training running on Turbo Brain voyager (TBV) 3.2 (Brain Innovation, Maastricht, The Netherlands)
